Lecture: Fundamental Derivative Rules — Power, Exponential, Logarithmic, Sum & Difference

Objective

To learn and apply key rules of differentiation that allow us to compute derivatives quickly and reliably without using the limit definition every time.

Review: Why Rules?

In the last lecture, we used the limit definition to compute the derivative of functions like:

  • f(x)=x2⇒f′(x)=2xf(x) = x^2 \Rightarrow f'(x) = 2xf(x)=x2⇒f′(x)=2x
  • f(x)=1x⇒f′(x)=−1x2f(x) = \frac{1}{x} \Rightarrow f'(x) = -\frac{1}{x^2}f(x)=x1​⇒f′(x)=−x21​

These calculations can be tedious. Fortunately, mathematics gives us general rules that apply to broad classes of functions — making computation efficient and systematic.

The Power Rule

If f(x)=xnf(x) = x^nf(x)=xn, then:

f′(x)=nxn−1,for any real number nf'(x) = nx^{n - 1}, \quad \text{for any real number } n f′(x)=nxn−1,for any real number n

Examples:

  • f(x)=x3⇒f′(x)=3x2f(x) = x^3 \Rightarrow f'(x) = 3x^2f(x)=x3⇒f′(x)=3x2
  • f(x)=x−2⇒f′(x)=−2x−3f(x) = x^{-2} \Rightarrow f'(x) = -2x^{-3}f(x)=x−2⇒f′(x)=−2x−3
  • f(x)=x=x1/2⇒f′(x)=12x−1/2f(x) = \sqrt{x} = x^{1/2} \Rightarrow f'(x) = \frac{1}{2}x^{-1/2}f(x)=x​=x1/2⇒f′(x)=21​x−1/2

Exponential Functions: exe^xex

The natural exponential function has a beautiful property:

ddx(ex)=ex\frac{d}{dx}(e^x) = e^x dxd​(ex)=ex

Natural Logarithm: ln⁡(x)\ln(x)ln(x)

For x>0x > 0x>0:

ddx(ln⁡x)=1x\frac{d}{dx}(\ln x) = \frac{1}{x} dxd​(lnx)=x1​

This was proven in the last lecture using the limit definition.

Sum and Difference Rule

If f(x)=g(x)+h(x)f(x) = g(x) + h(x)f(x)=g(x)+h(x), then:

f′(x)=g′(x)+h′(x)f'(x) = g'(x) + h'(x) f′(x)=g′(x)+h′(x)

If f(x)=g(x)−h(x)f(x) = g(x) - h(x)f(x)=g(x)−h(x), then:

f′(x)=g′(x)−h′(x)f'(x) = g'(x) - h'(x) f′(x)=g′(x)−h′(x)

Example:

f(x)=x3+5x2−7x+9⇒f′(x)=3x2+10x−7f(x) = x^3 + 5x^2 - 7x + 9 \Rightarrow f'(x) = 3x^2 + 10x - 7 f(x)=x3+5x2−7x+9⇒f′(x)=3x2+10x−7

Constant Multiple Rule

If f(x)=c⋅g(x)f(x) = c \cdot g(x)f(x)=c⋅g(x), then:

f′(x)=c⋅g′(x)f'(x) = c \cdot g'(x) f′(x)=c⋅g′(x)

Example:

f(x)=5x3⇒f′(x)=5⋅3x2=15x2f(x) = 5x^3 \Rightarrow f'(x) = 5 \cdot 3x^2 = 15x^2 f(x)=5x3⇒f′(x)=5⋅3x2=15x2

Summary Table of Rules

Function Derivative
xnx^nxn nxn−1nx^{n - 1}nxn−1
exe^xex exe^xex
ln⁡x\ln xlnx 1x\frac{1}{x}x1​
c⋅f(x)c \cdot f(x)c⋅f(x) c⋅f′(x)c \cdot f'(x)c⋅f′(x)
f(x)±g(x)f(x) \pm g(x)f(x)±g(x) f′(x)±g′(x)f'(x) \pm g'(x)f′(x)±g′(x)

Practice Exercises

1. Apply Power Rule

Differentiate:

  • (a) f(x)=x5f(x) = x^5f(x)=x5
  • (b) f(x)=x−3f(x) = x^{-3}f(x)=x−3
  • (c) f(x)=x3f(x) = \sqrt[3]{x}f(x)=3x​
  • (d) f(x)=1x4f(x) = \frac{1}{x^4}f(x)=x41​

2. Sum/Difference and Constant Multiples

Differentiate:

  • (a) f(x)=3x4+5x2−7f(x) = 3x^4 + 5x^2 - 7f(x)=3x4+5x2−7
  • (b) f(x)=x3−1x+4f(x) = x^3 - \frac{1}{x} + 4f(x)=x3−x1​+4
  • (c) f(x)=2x+5x1/3f(x) = 2\sqrt{x} + 5x^{1/3}f(x)=2x​+5x1/3

3. Exponential and Logarithmic Derivatives

Simplify the expression using log identities before differentiating:

  • (a) f(x)=5exf(x) = 5e^xf(x)=5ex
  • (b) f(x)=ln⁡(x3)f(x) = \ln(x^3)f(x)=ln(x3)
  • (c) f(x)=ln⁡(x2x)f(x) = \ln\left(\frac{x^2}{\sqrt{x}}\right)f(x)=ln(x​x2​)
  • (d) f(x)=ln⁡(ex3)f(x) = \ln(e^{x^3})f(x)=ln(ex3)

4. Mix It Up

Differentiate:

  • (a) f(x)=ex+x2−1xf(x) = e^x + x^2 - \frac{1}{x}f(x)=ex+x2−x1​
  • (b) f(x)=x3+ln⁡xf(x) = x^3 + \ln xf(x)=x3+lnx

5. Rewriting Functions to Apply Rules

Differentiate the following functions by rewriting them into a form where the power rule or other known rules can be applied.

  • (a) f(x)=x34x2f(x) = \frac{\sqrt[4]{x^3}}{x^2}f(x)=x24x3​​
  • (b) f(x)=5x1/3+3x−1x2f(x) = \frac{5}{x^{1/3}} + 3\sqrt{x} - \frac{1}{x^2}f(x)=x1/35​+3x​−x21​
  • (c) f(x)=x2+xx1/2f(x) = \frac{x^2 + \sqrt{x}}{x^{1/2}}f(x)=x1/2x2+x​​
  • (d) f(x)=1x23+2x1/5f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{x^2}} + \frac{2}{x^{1/5}}f(x)=3x2​1​+x1/52​

Extra Advanced Problems

1. Function with Parameters (for analysis)

Let:

f(x)=axn+bln⁡(x)+cexf(x) = ax^n + b\ln(x) + ce^x f(x)=axn+bln(x)+cex

  • (a) Compute f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) in terms of a,b,c,na, b, c, na,b,c,n
  • (b) For what values of a,b,ca, b, ca,b,c is f′(x)=0f'(x) = 0f′(x)=0 at x=1x = 1x=1?
  • (c) Analyze whether f(x)f(x)f(x) can have a local minimum at x=1x = 1x=1

2. Piecewise Polynomial Analysis

Let

f(x)={x3+2x2−x+1if x<14x2−3x+2if x≥1f(x) = \begin{cases} x^3 + 2x^2 - x + 1 & \text{if } x < 1 \\ 4x^2 - 3x + 2 & \text{if } x \geq 1 \end{cases} f(x)={x3+2x2−x+14x2−3x+2​if x<1if x≥1​

Tasks:

  • (a) Is f(x)f(x)f(x) continuous at x=1x = 1x=1?
  • (b) Is f(x)f(x)f(x) differentiable at x=1x = 1x=1?

Use left-hand and right-hand derivatives.

3. Log-Exponential Combination

Let

f(x)=ln⁡x+5ex−3x3+2xf(x) = \ln x + 5e^x - 3x^3 + 2x f(x)=lnx+5ex−3x3+2x

Tasks:

  • (a) Find f′(x)f'(x)f′(x)
  • (b) Find all x>0x > 0x>0 such that f′(x)=0f'(x) = 0f′(x)=0

Use algebra to simplify, and solve graphically or numerically if needed.

4. Prove the Power Rule

Use the limit definition to prove the power rule for:

f(x)=xnf(x) = x^nf(x)=xn, where n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N

5. Cost-Analysis Word Problem

A company’s total cost to produce xxx units is modeled by:

C(x)=10x3−15x2+500x+1000C(x) = 10x^3 - 15x^2 + 500x + 1000 C(x)=10x3−15x2+500x+1000

Tasks:

  • (a) Find the marginal cost function C′(x)C'(x)C′(x)
  • (b) Compute C′(10)C'(10)C′(10). Interpret the result.
  • (c) For which xxx is the marginal cost minimized?

6. Population Dynamics

The population of bacteria over time ttt (in hours) is:

P(t)=−100et+50t+18000P(t) = -100e^t + 50t + 18000 P(t)=−100et+50t+18000

Tasks:

  • (a) Find P′(t)P'(t)P′(t)
  • (b) Find when the population stops increasing
  • (c) Find when the population seizes to exist

7. Logarithmic Inverse

  • (a) Show that f(x)=ln⁡(x)f(x) = \ln(x)f(x)=ln(x) is the inverse of g(x)=exg(x) = e^xg(x)=ex, and that:

ddxln⁡(x)=1eln⁡(x)=1x\frac{d}{dx} \ln(x) = \frac{1}{e^{\ln(x)}} = \frac{1}{x} dxd​ln(x)=eln(x)1​=x1​

Wrap-Up

You now know the core rules of differentiation:

  • Power Rule
  • Logarithmic Rule
  • Exponential Rule
  • Sum, Difference, and Constant Multiple Rules

These rules are the foundation of fast differentiation and will prepare you for the next tools: product, quotient, and chain rules.
